The "Responding to Urgent needs of Survivors of the Holocaust Act" or the "RUSH Act" includes a table of contents with sections on purposes, findings, and activities for health, independence, and longevity of Holocaust survivors. It covers definitions, grants, organization, state plans, consumer contributions, and programs authorized to address elder abuse, neglect, and exploitation. Sec. 111. Innovation to improve transportation for older Holocaust survivors. Sec. 121. Designation of individual within Administration. Sec. 122. Annual report to congress. Sec. 201. Nutrition services. TITLE II--NUTRITION SERVICES FOR ALL OLDER INDIVIDUALS. SEC. 2. PURPOSES. The Act aims to provide nutrition services and transportation assistance for older individuals, specifically Holocaust survivors. It includes designating a responsible individual within the Administration on Aging and creating a grant program for transportation services. During the Holocaust, 6,000,000 Jews and millions from other groups were murdered. Approximately 127,000 Holocaust survivors remain in the US, with many aging and needing support. Providers face high demand without additional funding. Most survivors are over 75, with many in their 80s and 90s. Holocaust survivors who emigrated to the US from the former Soviet Union after 1965 are vulnerable due to poverty. They continue to suffer from mental and physical scars of the Holocaust. Institutionalized settings can retraumatize survivors by reintroducing past traumas. Approximately 2/3 of Holocaust survivors live alone, which is a risk factor for institutionalization. Low-income survivors rely heavily on social service programs for personal care, meals, transportation, counseling, and mental health support. TITLE I--RESPONDING TO THE NEEDS OF HOLOCAUST SURVIVORS. Subtitle A--Definition, Grants, and Other Programs. SEC. 101. DEFINITION. Section 102 of the Older Americans Act of 1965 is amended to include the definition of a "Holocaust survivor" as an individual who lived in a country under Nazi regime, occupation, or control between 1933 and 1945. The amendment to Section 102 of the Older Americans Act of 1965 defines a "Holocaust survivor" as someone who fled from a country under Nazi regime, occupation, or control between 1933 and 1945, was persecuted on various bases, and was a member of a persecuted group by the Nazis. SEC. 102 of the Older Americans Act of 1965 is amended to include "older individuals who are Holocaust survivors" in certain paragraphs. Section 306 of the Older Americans Act of 1965 is amended to include "older individuals who are Holocaust survivors" in specific paragraphs. Section 306 of the Older Americans Act of 1965 is amended to include "older individuals who are Holocaust survivors" in specific paragraphs, emphasizing their placement and support in various programs. SEC. 104 of the Older Americans Act of 1965 is amended to include "older individuals who are Holocaust survivors" in specific paragraphs related to state plans. This amendment highlights the support and inclusion of Holocaust survivors in various programs. SEC. 105 amends the Older Americans Act to include "older individuals who are Holocaust survivors" in specific sections. SEC. 107 amends the Older Americans Act to include older individuals who are Holocaust survivors in the prevention of elder abuse, neglect, and exploitation. SEC. 111 introduces innovation to improve transportation for this specific group. The Assistant Secretary will award grants to nonprofit organizations to improve transportation services for older individuals, including non-emergency transportation to medical appointments and shopping for essential items. Preference will be given to Holocaust survivors. Grants or contracts will be for a minimum of 5 years. Nonprofit organizations must use the funds for demonstration projects or to provide technical assistance to local transit providers and senior support groups. The organization will receive funds to develop innovative transportation services for older individuals, including volunteer driver programs and sustainable transportation programs. The organization will develop innovative transportation services for older individuals, including volunteer driver programs and sustainable transportation options. This includes transferring automobiles for services, providing information on transportation options, and developing models for comprehensive integrated transportation services. The Assistant Secretary gives preference to organizations with experience working with Holocaust survivors. Consultation is required to improve transportation assistance for survivors. The needs of Survivors of the Holocaust Act requires eligible entities to have extensive experience working with older individuals. Subtitle C of the Needs of Survivors of the Holocaust Act authorizes the Administrator for Community Living to designate a person with expertise in Holocaust survivor issues to implement services for older Holocaust survivors. Additionally, an annual report on the status and needs of older Holocaust survivors must be submitted to Congress. TITLE II--NUTRITION SERVICES FOR ALL OLDER INDIVIDUALS

SEC. 201. NUTRITION SERVICES. Section 339(2) of the Older Americans Act of 1065 is amended to adjust and fund programs to meet special health-related or dietary needs, including religious, cultural, or ethnic requirements. Individuals distributing nutrition services are encouraged to engage in these efforts. The Older Americans Act Amendments of 2006 encourage nutrition service providers to engage with homebound older individuals and be aware of warning signs to reduce isolation and promote wellbeing. Additionally, a study will analyze providers' abilities to obtain special foods for religious, dietary, or ethnic needs.
